sn35.131:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
sn35.131:1.2: Then the householder Nakula’s father went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.131:1.3: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
sn35.131:1.4: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?”
sn35.131:1.5: “Householder, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn35.131:1.6: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
sn35.131:1.7: their consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
sn35.131:1.8: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
sn35.131:1.9: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …
sn35.131:1.10: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
